user_review: I've never been to the physical location, but during this pandemic, my need for Poutine went sadly unanswered, so I ordered some. Boy oh boy had I been missing out during the past 4 years of living in Montreal! The poutines I've had since (la Royale, le Fred Caillou and le reggae) have all been surprisingly different and amazingly delicious. The food comes in those small, square takeout boxes which made me feel disappointed because it didn't seem like a lot. Oh was I ever wrong! That small box is jam packed to the she and leaking out! Once I got it out on a plate, it was almost overflowing! I've tried their hamburgers too and if that's not the cutest, juiciest little 5$ burger, I don't know what is. Basically, I finally understand the hype and I've been craving it almost daily since. Looks like it's time to order a Poutine!

Poutine loyalties and rivalries in Montreal run deep but I won't partake in those, and will enjoy a good, filing poutine when I feel that unmistakeable urge to consume comfort food. La Banquise is good enough to warrant me forcing my visiting friends to walk a couple of kilometres in any weather and potentially stand in line, in order to sample their creations. I have even driven there from home for pick-up, and had a chance to appreciate their sci-fi pager-pod order notification system. Efficient and no-nonsense.Let's begin with the obvious: unless you know your stomach stretches like an accordion, don't order a large poutine for one. Proficient out-of-town eaters have gazed with awe,  reverence and maybe a touch of incredulity on my large T-Rex upon its arrival at the table.Vegetarian tastes are abundantly catered for and the atmosphere is wonderfully complemented by an alcohol license and the consequent Québécois beer selection. Nothing that would impress a micro-brewpub, but a good complement to the carby comfort food before you nonetheless.Considering the enormous customer  throughput and selection, I think La Banquise is worth a trek from anywhere within a two mile radius, and an Uber ride from most other places. Whether it's your dinner spot or you budgeted these calories into your evening by having a light dinner and first rounds of beers somewhere else, come one, come all.If you're dining in: come, eat, be merry and get out, as there's plenty of people waiting!

We picked up la banquise for late night take out. Ordered the scooby. The poutine was layered with toppings, not just on top. And lavishly sauced, yes please! Can't say I've ever had so many weird choices of unexpected toppings and flavors that just still leave my mouth watering. Even reheated as leftovers was still bomb. Service was friendly and fast regardless of the line being out the door and packed like sardines on a cold pre-Covid Montreal night. A total experience and can't wait to go back

Been in Montreal forever but never tried this joint until recently. We got two large orders of the "Scooby" and "Savoyeur" poutine. They feature toppings like bacon, minced beef, fried pickles, ceasar sauce or sour cream.I was at the take out counter and saw only two container sizes, regular and large. The regular seems too small and large ended up being way too large for one person, and I can usually eat a lot. $40 later for two orders, this is on the expensive side for fries. The toppings were generous, but the cheese curds were not. You get a mountain of fries and something about the sauce is just lacking in salt, it is slightly too sweet for my liking.Perhaps this is the kind of thing to consume in moderation, it left me with a sickly feeling and just not worth the price or wait to get your food.Try it once if you must but if you love poutine, there are a lot better choices elsewhere.

Such a staple to bring friends who are visiting Montreal to. However, the line ups are kind of crazy which is the main reason for my lower stars. On a hot summer's day or a colder winter day, it's rough when there isn't a way to make a reservation or grab a number (and return later on when a table frees up). And most of Montreal's either a pretty hot or cold day save for the 4 weeks or so of spring/fall each year. The food itself is good and the portions are hefty. They also have a wide variety of toppings that's pretty novel.

I ate here twice and still cannot comprehend why this place is so popular. I am giving an extra star for the friendly staff & trying to accommodate a group of 6 people to find a table for 6 people on a rainy day.

There are much better putin places out there but this one is there a long time thus the cult following but really not that good at all. Been there twice though so I can tell that the quality is consistently bad.

Love love love this place...in the summers they have the outside done in too which is so magical. We love coming here as it's so close to home. Love their Fred calliou and the the shootout! So flavorful with all the meats and we get some extra gravy/sauce. Their servers are so sweet always!

I have never in my life had Poutine til I came here, realistically it sounds like it's right up my alley. How can you go wrong with crispy fries, gravy, and meat?!Well, to begin with, my meat and gravy were overly salty, for me... But still edible.What gave me a bad taste was the customer service to be honest, and I'm not sure if it's just a Montréal thing, but since I didn't speak French I felt like I was left on the back burner.Maybe I will visit this place again when I touch up on my French.Can't say I hated the place, but also can't say I loved it, so I'll be fair and stay in the middle.

Authentic poutine!!And they have a vegan version? Hell yass. There is always a line but totally worth it! This place is pretty party friendly as you can bring your group of friends to dine here. To top it off, the prices are very reasonable with most items under 10. I ordered a regular sized and my SO ordered the large sized poutine. The gravy was definitely the star of this show. The vegan cheese was a bonus. If you have not had La Banquise poutine, then you have not yet had real poutine. Come check it out!

You can easily spot La Banquise from the light yellow exterior and the line up on both sides of the entrance. One queue is for takeaway and the other is for seating. The takeaway line usually goes quicker. I'm told their prime time is 3am, after everyone is done with the bars and clubs - so prepare for the wait if you're planning to hit up this place after a night out. Once seated, the servers will take your order and kindly ask for you to pay the bill first to make things easier since they're so busy. Here is why I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5. When the server brought our receipts over, there are two tip amounts indicated on the receipt for you to choose from. One of the members of our party had just enough for his poutine and a little bit of change, but not enough to cover the minimum tip amount. The server pointed this out right away saying that he has to pay the minimum tip amount (and he wasn't exactly nice about it). I personally didn't like the idea of this. Although I'm sure 99% of us tip everywhere we go, tip is customary but it is not mandatory. It is based on the service, which tbh wasn't that great.Now onto the food - they have over 30 different variations of poutine. It'll be hard to choose but guaranteed that they'll all be delicious. It's fries, gravy, cheese and a bunch of other toppings - cheap, greasy food! What's not to love? :P The first time I went, we all got our own poutine and it was way too much. The portions were huge. This time around, I got a regular to share with my boyfriend and it was perfect for the two of us.

Was lucky enough on my trip to Montreal to have 2 well reviewed poutine places right nearby. We came by here to try their poutine since we saw such good reviews. I had already tried the chicken one from Ma Poule Mouillee so decided to try the beef and hotdog one from here. It came out fairly quickly and we went home to try it out. I thought the food was good but a bit too salty for my taste and didnt seem like anything too special. My friend liked his but also didn't seem too crazy about it. Other thing would be that it was sitting in the container for the 5 minute ride home. I dont think it would make that much of a difference but maybe that affected its taste? Seeing all the other reviews, I feel like I need to give this place another shot at some point to try other poutines that they have. Would consider swinging by again.

I don't typically like poutine but the fact that this spot is open 24/7 and has so many different poutine creations swayed my opinion. I came with a group of friends after being at the club and the wait was around 15-20min to get in (there was a lineup outside). By the time we were seated and had ordered, the line had doubled, so the place is obviously pretty popular amongst locals. I ordered La Taquise which was sour cream, guacamole and tomatoes and I loved it because I love tacos lol. The "regular" portion is huge, I took some home because it was too much, even with my hungry self after a night of dancing. They also have regular breakfast and general dishes on the menu if you're not keen for poutine.

When in Montreal, eat poutine! I came here with a group of 6 friends for lunch on Saturday and it was approximately a 40-minute wait. The time went by pretty quickly and could tell that the staff was really efficient in getting people in and out. The interior is actually somewhat roomy - They really use the space well. There are brick walls, yellow and orange color scheme, along with winding tree branches on the ceiling. It's wacky and colorful decor, with a comfortable and bustling atmosphere. Once we were seated, I asked our waiter if he would be able to charge my cell phone because we had a full day of sightseeing planned after lunch. He accommodated the request which I very much appreciated.The menu of poutine options is quite extensive. I had a tough time choosing between La Royale (pulled pork, bacon + apples) and La T-Rex (ground beef, pepperoni, bacon + hot dog sausage). I asked the waiter for his opinion and he suggested La Royale because that is a unique combination that won't be found anywhere else. I am not a fan of gravy over my fries, so I ordered it sans gravy. All of us got the regular size poutine option, which was still humongous! There was a ton of deliciously crispy french fries, melty cheese curds, a fair amount of pulled pork which was tasty, tender and full of flavor. The bacon wasn't crunchy enough for me and I didn't feel there were enough apples in the dish. I believe I would have been more satisfied with La T-Rex. I was able to try some of my friends' poutine and I enjoyed the one with hot dog sausage. The hot dog was really juicy and seasoned well. I didn't really like the one with smoked meat - The combination of the meat and gravy didn't agree with me. I would probably try another poutine restaurant next time I am in Montreal, but I wouldn't mind returning here to have the La T-Rex!

I have been to Banquise last summer. It was a huge line up, so I did take out. Honestly, I wasn't impressed. It was really bland. I think this place is overly hyped out. So let's give a second chance, I decided to order through UberEats this spring season. The experience of the poutine this time, was slightly better. I ordered La Taquise, which is vegetarian. Topped with Guacamole, tomato and sour cream. I felt the taste was missing the zing. The Banquise is super popular, so I assume their other poutines are good. As their vegetarian options, they need to bring couple of notches up with its flavor.

-Canadian cash only but they will let you know with a sign before you sit and provide you with an ATM at the front-You can't order alcohol if sitting outside, but outside may be the quickest option for service.-The vegan poutine was bland with cheese that would not completely melt. I would not recommend it here. Copper Branch is where you need to go.

I have had poutine more times than I can remember as a former resident of Montréal. From the cafeteria in the engineering building at McGill to burger King on St. Catherine's across from the Bay. There is just something happy about this wonderful French Canadian comfort food. It certainly made me happy when I was feeling anxiety about taking finals as a student. Having deeper pockets these days, the Bank is my go to spot for poutine when I'm in Montréal. Having had the poutine here and then a few days later at anothee well regarded eatery (Radio Cafe in Beaupré Quebec) really helped me to appreciate just how good the quality of the poutine is at the Bank. They weren't remotely comparable.The smoked meat poutine remains my favorite. Something about how the smoked meat flavor enhances the poutine gravy taste without adding a ton of grease like sausage would. On a carefree non health conscious day this might be my favorite meal in the world. The vegetarian poutine was also tops, especially if you add some chopped spicy peppers to the dish. I had to take a star off my review for our waitress, however. We had leftovers yet she stacked our bowls one on top of another. I called her out regarding contaminating our food and yet she still denied wrongdoing. "The food doesn't touch" she said.I know the Bank gets super hectic and is probably a tough place to work but cmon!

I have a confession to make: my wife is a cardiac rehab nurse and I know a grown man shouldn't eat this stuff. I know better. To make things worse, my first experience with poutine was awful and I secretly hoped I would never try it again.So then a local tells me I have to try La Banquise before I write the food group off. Thanks for the recommendation, I'll give that a try if I'm ever in the mood...haha...Well I tried it tonight  and the poutine was delicious. The fries were crisp and tasty, the gravy  was silky smooth and tasted great, even the sliced hotdog on top was good. OK I see what the excitement is about. I know better...I'm so disappointed in myself...but I'm so happy so who cares?

3.5 stars. I came here as a tourist. Here are my observations:-If you get there after 7, the line goes out the door so plan to be there early.-The place is small and not good for big size parties.-The food is delicious but the calories are off the chart.-They offer both vegetarian and vegan options too (nice)-They take only cash or Canadian debit cards but we found out they would accept American dollars too?-The place smells like grease and potato and eventually your nose gets used to it.-You have to try poutine at least once in Montréal and I liked my nacho style poutine ;)

Fries. Cheese curds. Gravy. +++toppingsWhat's not to love? Sooo many different types of poutine.. there are other food choices as well but if you're not coming for the poutine then don't bother. Usually a long line up but the turnover is quite quick and our table of 6 was seated within 20 minutes on a busy Sunday evening. Service is fine. Every time we visit Montreal, this is a go to spot. Can range from $9-20 depending on toppings and size (regular or large). French fries are fresh. Only downfall is parking is not great. Limited street parking.

Get yourself a group of friends who are willing to order different poutines to share and try. I had my heart set on the classic but my eyes wandered to the La Matty. It was delicious. For the classic, I wish they added more cheese curds and gravy since it was on the drier side. The fries for both were on the softer side (I prefer the fries a little more well done). Your order arrives to the table along with the bill, which will need to be settled prior to stuffing your face.

There are plenty of options to go about at La Banquise for a poutine. However, don't be distracted! Go straight for the Classic Poutine, or better yet, if you're vegan, get the Classic Vegan Poutine! Whether or not you're vegan, both options are AMAZING. We didn't understand why having fries for a meal was a thing, so we ordered a burger as well. For our first meal in Montréal, La Banquise was a major win! The gravy and the cheese curds... omg. If you like creamy things, you're gonna love this! The burger should not be overlooked either! The way they make the patty competes with how good Shake Shack makes theirs!The place is tiny, you have your kitchen which you can see, the dining room, the small waiting area, and the pick-up area. NOTE: CASH ONLY, luckily they take Canadian AND American dollars!!! They conveniently have an ATM located inside the restaurant.

If you want to be overwhelmed and in poutine heaven please come here. Id probably say it's more fitting to come when it's freezing cold outside in Montreal, and not super hot and summer like we did. But nevertheless food is wow.

Friday night, arrive just before the line up was out the door. We were a party of 10 and the staff was quite helpful and friendly to accommodate our party size.Food was plentiful, so if you were a party of 4, 3 regulars size poutine would suffice. After a while the fries and salt became overwhelming but until then, it was delicious and filling.Payment is only cash or debit.Busy...can't believe they open 24 hrs

This is the place to go in Montreal for a poutine they have so many options to choose from and they always have a special one for the month. The ambiance is a little tight because this place is always full. So no private conversation.I always go with friends or partner because we let each other try and have different combination. The price are affordable the place like I said is always full but its also tight. They have a very small restaurant and the space is limited. Every time I went to place was packed and people were waiting outside including myself. You hope it dont start to rain.The tables are very colourful and full of art. I feel like it makes it more cozy. I always seem to pick a late time to go around 7-9pm thats when the craving come.

Came here for  a late night snack and having heard about the long wait, I came here after 1a and there was no wait! Had the classic poutine and service was great Tourist tip -- bring cash , they didn't accept any CC ( T least the ones I had)

Stopped by La Banquise while waiting on a friend who was getting a tattoo (at Sans Regret, HIGHLY recommend) and had a regular poutine and a hot dog. The poutine was pretty good, and for the smaller size, it was pretty damn sizeable so beware. The gravy wasn't too thick and gelatinous (cough, smokes poutinerie, cough), I felt it was a touch sweet though, possibly because of the onion in it. Either way it was super good. The hot dog I ordered steamed, with no toppings cause I'm boring. It was also fairly good, nothing revolutionary obviously.I'd recommend La Banquise if you're looking for a poutine fix anytime day or night.

Le Rachel to go. Mushrooms, onions and bell peppers with fries smothered in gravy and cheese. The quick way to get your hands on any of these poutine variations is the take out line. It's a party in here with lively staff for the 24/7 establishment. Space is quite small and quite busy. Come one come all there is room for all.

Disclaimer: I'm not a fan of poutine. The reason is that I prefer my fries crispy. So, maybe my review is biased. However, this was not the best poutine I had in Montreal. I ordered the shoot-out that had bacon, sausage etc. It was delicious but very heavy and greasy so overall it was overwhelming. We also tried their own brewed beer, French style (blond and Blanche) and they were really nice.

I've been here twice. I really like the poutine here. High quality cheap eats.This time I had a burger and share a poutine with my friend. The banquise burger was very good and inexpensive. Tasty and juicy. Also perfect size for me. The burger, hot dog and sandwich can all be ordered as combo with fries and soft drinks.The poutines I have tried were the south-west, the three meats and the B.O.M.  All were tasty to me. Our waiter was very thoughtful and kindly reminded us the regular size poutine should be enough for us. We barely finished it. Also had a free refill of the coffee.The only down side was that there were some flies flying around us.

Pooouttineeee. We made the mistake of trying to split a large between 2 people... I believe we got enough food to actually feed 4 people. You get SO much food for your money - a lot of greasy heart-attack inducing food, but hey, we all need that sometimes. We came after 11 AM on a Saturday, and it was not too busy yet. We got the B.O.M, which is bacon, onion, sausages Merguez. The cheese curds were fantastic. Bacon and sausages were good as well. Great party food, midnight snack food, studying at the library food, you get my drift.

I've never met a plateI could not cleanBefore I ate Banquise poutine.That just about sums it up. Full, really full. Heaping portions of poutine.La banquise, which translates "the ice" in French (I've also been told it means "benches" in Québécois) has nothing to do with ice, and even the soft drinks don't come on the rocks. La Banquise, despite the name, is all about the hot poutine.I took on a large portion of La Festival: Ground beef, swiss cheese, hot peppers & topped with onion rings.  Or, shall I say, drowned in a half-pound of ground beef, BLANKETED in Swiss cheese, covered in another layer of tongue-warming peppers, and enveloped in a top-layer of big, thick, crispy onion rings. While I would preferred a little less gravy, but the taste was superb. My wife had the Montréal Burger: Smoked meat, swiss cheese, pickle, tomatoes, lettuce, mustard, on pretzel burger bun. It's awesome. Schwartz's better watch out ... this stands toe-to-toe with their smoked meat sandwich.  And, oh yeah, hers came with a gigantic side of poutine.As for poutine, no one in Canada (IMHO) matches La Banquise in volume, taste, or selection (30+ types of poutine. What a place; I can't wait to come back.So many poutines, so little time!

When you got locals that go to a tourist trap, is it really a trap? It's an iconic food destination that you'd probably want to try at least once. What's not to love about fries, cheese, and tons of gravy? Lesbehonest, can that combination ever be bad? Is it the best that Canada has to offer? I can't say that it is or isn't but it's not going to disappoint that's for sure. It's like having a bad slice of pizza, you'll still eat it because how bad can the worst be? This is no where near the worst and you'll gladly enjoy every bite of it. I honestly can't say that I've ever even had bad poutine because it'll always be good enough to want to finish it anyway. There are no short comings here and the portions are pretty ridiculous in the best possible way. Be prepared to wait if you're dining in, this place usually has a line, but to-go ordering is a breeze that you may want to opt for if it's a nice day. Overwhelming choices of toppings to choose from that it'll satisfy anyone's picky eater of the party's heart. There is a lot of regret with each mouthful you shove face with but sometimes living a little is necessary. 24/7 making it the ultimate drunk food of choice to soak up your 1 shot wonder ass to sobriety. Make good choices. This is a bad one physically, but oh so good mentally. Stay fat mother suckers

Well the food is not the main reason I had to give a 1 star to them. I made a reservation for 22 on the birthday of my 12 years old son and here are the reasons, in my opinion, they've failed so bad:1) they divided the party in 2 tables that were in the middle of a passage to the patio and kept complaining that we were disturbing it... why they didn't put us in a corner then?2) Only when I got there they told us we couldn't have a birthday cake! My son had a super Mario bros cake and was very disappointed he couldn't sing it with his friends.3) one of the guests ordered a vegetarian poutine that came with bacon!!!! Lucky him he's not allergic.

This was highly recommended by my boyfriend so it was a must when making the trip to Montreal. Service was very busy one of their employees hung up on me while I was trying to ask them a question prior coming to the restaurant, and then waited outside in line for 20 minutes because they don't take reservations; but didn't feel too long of a wait, and it's also open 24 hours in case you want to visit during non-peak hours.We ordered the La Taquise and La Elvis regulars to share between 4 people and it was more than enough and for us! But due to the demand and high volume of the poutine, I'm not sure how long the fries sit for because the fries did come out a soggy but nonetheless was a solid poutine first experience.

At 3am, there is no line, no wait.The BFF says this is standard poutine. This is my first time having poutine outside Chicago and I prefer the Chicago version over the Canadian style because the the Canadian style is just a soupy mess and the sauce is on the sweeter side. The fries were not crispy at all and the super saucey pulled pork (WTF?) covering the fries sure didn't help make it any less soggy. Two cups of poutine sauce was also provided on the side... Oh em gee!Service was super friendly and helpful.

La Banquise is open 24/7 and seems to be a great place to socialize with friends and enjoy a big meal after a long night out..Rate: 4.5/5.La Panamorix (Regular $11.60)Smoked meat, mushrooms, sour creamThis dish has a generous amount of shaved smoked meat, sautéed mushrooms, and sour cream. I love mushrooms myself, so I just had to order this one. It was extremely savoury, Overall, it was humongous but scrumptious, and we couldn't even finish of it half between three girls. ..Rating: 4.5/5.La Savoyarde (Regular $10.95)Bacon, Onions, Swiss cheese,  sour cream, cheese curds This dish had a very unique taste to it, however I personally do not prefer caramel iced onions on my fries, I like them on my burgers. It was a little on the salty side and I believe the three of us agreed that the Panamorix was better, however it would be heaven for onion lovers as they really stack them on.
I had 'La Rachel', all I can say was she was really tasty and worth the post meal bloating.

Name a better 24hr poutine spot, I dare you! When in Montréal this is a must-visit. There is always a line, but the wait is always worth it! You can go at anytime of the day to get you're poutine fix. Ambiance (4/5): Very welcoming, loud with good music, colourful interior and friendly staff! Food (5/5): Large variety of poutine options and more, there's something for everyone! Can't really go wrong with whatever you choose. The fries have the right kind of crunch and soft texture when you bite into it. But don't even get me started on the cheese curds... it makes the poutine what it is! If I'm ever back in Montréal, this will be my first stop!

This place is always packed. Line looks long but turn over is quick so it moves fast.La Hotdog poutine: can't go wrong with this one, delicious and buttering with flavor. Probably shortened my life by 1 year after finishing it. I bet it's 1200+ calories.Also recommend Banquise beer. It's a local Quebec golden pilsner ale.I took one star off cause the music was so loud you could barely hear the person you came with.
Poutine is my favorite, this shop throws out some wicked poutine in the plate.Very very good poutine.
Whatever you do. Don't order the chicken and pea sandwich. The poutine was fantastic but that's about it lol

Poutine is what they are know for her at La Banquise. A lot of local friends have told me there are better spots for poutine in Montreal but this is "THE SPOT" for late night after drinking and partying go to place to fill up on some greasy food. They are also open 24H so another reason why they are the spot for after hours. When you pull up there are usually 2 lines at the door one is for their take away counter and the second line is for dine in. When I arrived at 4am the dine in line was less than 4 people and the take away was about 15 people. The restaurant is a little crowded with lots of tables and if you have a big group be prepared to have the group split up into different tables. I ordered their poutine called the T-Rex which has sausage and ground beef in it along with the usual squeaky cheese and gravy. The gravy was very great tasting not too salty but the sausage was a little salty but I but I don't think it bothered me too much after a night of partying. They offer 2 sizes a regular and large, I opted for their regular and good thing I did because their large was served in a bowl like the ones East Side Mario serves their salad in.I will be back for some more poutine and try their other offerings of poutine.

I've had better poutine in America. My Canadian friend recommended this place to me, so I was pretty excited to visit. I came here in the pouring rain close to midnight on a Saturday night, and it was hopping. I figured that was a good sign, but I was wrong.I ordered La Royale, which features pulled pork, apples, and bacon. The apple adds a good tart kick to the otherwise carnivorous dish. The whole thing was too salty and heavy. The cool combination of flavors did not overcome the deficiencies in the fries, gravy, and cheese curds.I only got to try one of the poutines here though, so it's also possible that I managed to order the one thing here that's sub-par.

Incredible. There is almost always a line out the door with good reason. This place is good, real good.I ordered the TRex and my husband ordered the Royale. The fries are perfectly crispy. The curds are melted on the heat of the plate. The gravy is salty and delicious. But your choice of toppings are what make this dish at La Banquise! I am a big fan of the hot dog and ground beef. I would recommend ordering a regular size because IMO one of these can feed two people.Service is super friendly and despite how crowded and busy this restaurant can be, they were all so attentive to us. Food came out quickly. They would have to be efficient considering the popularity. Overall a must when in Montreal.

If you want your fix of poutine in a variety of flavors, La Banquise is the destination for that. But beware, it's quite hard to get in at peak hours. It's definitely advised to come early. They try to get people in and out though, but that comes with the business model. The poutine itself is good, however I probably wouldn't come for the classic poutine but to try a crazy variety of special types of poutine. I order la taquise, which was essentially poutine with guacamole and sour cream which was pretty good. All the meat poutines are good and probably better choices than the non-meat ones. Overall, a staple of the Montreal restaurant scene and a good place to try unique poutine styles.

Overload on meat and all of the gravy stuff - this was one heavy poutine! I got the "la shoot" which is Italian sausage, bacon, and Montreal smoked meat of the large portion. Hugeeee portions, cheese and gravy was great. I also ordered the burger and it was (though seemingly simple) one of the better burgers I've had as well.Relatively small place, does get packed so would advise to come and try it out if you have spare time as well.

Amazing poutines and friendly staff! They have so many poutine options, it's ridiculous. I took a normal sized "Obelix Poutine" that is filled with smoked meat. I took it for take out and it was jam-packed with fries, sauce and amazing and tender meat. This place has come up a thousand times and today was the day. Finally had a chance to got and oh boy I wasn't disappointed. It has some parking spots in front but not a lot, so take the metro or public transport if you can. (Depending on the hour that you're visiting). It was simply delicious and filled me up to the brim. First couple bites were really good, but at the end it kinda hard to finish. **Take a small portion*** trust me, I'm a big guy, and there's things are filled to the top. Take a large portion for 2, but don't get cocky and take a large for one person. Have nothing to complain about this place. One of the most, If not, the most popular poutine restaurant in Montreal. 1 regular sized obelix poutine with a bottle of water was 14.45$.

I am just not a fan of their fries or their gravy. There are just too many better poutines out there. However, the place is really a favourite amongst Montrealers so you should definitely check it out and make your own opinion of it.

Talk about poutine!!! So many varieties and it's offered at all hours of the night! Oh man this place can be trouble.Not that it stops anyone from coming here. The lines can be crazy long but totally worth the wait. When I arrive, close to 11pm on a Friday night, the line was out the door and down the sidewalk a bit but I didn't wait too long. The dining room is jam packed, fitting as as many tables as possible to accommodate the crowds of people trying to sink their teeth into the tasty poutine.The menu is extensive and can be overwhelming but stick to what Montréal is known for, smoked meat. Pick anything topped with that and you are solid gold. The tender meat and gravy is so freaking good! Be warned the large plate of poutine is HUGE!They have a variety of locals beers available as well, bottle though.Also, they require payment first and are cash only, (maybe it's just on the weekend evenings?)Totally worth the glutinous feeling I had afterward!

First time having poutine ever! I put an order in for takeout, and got the hotdog poutine. The restaurant was packed and there was a huge line out the door. If you don't want to wait an hour outside in the cold, I recommend ordering take out. You should get your food in 10-15 minutes. I ordered the Grand size, and it was huge. It could easily feed 3 people. Since it was my first time having poutine, I don't really have anything to compare it to. There was plenty of hotdogs, cheese and gravy. The fries were not overly crispy at all, and the flavor of the gravy was mild. The hotdog quality was not as good as nathans or sabrett. What really made me upset was my food was ready, and was sitting there for 15+ minutes. I called in my order, and was told it would be ready in 15 minutes. I got there within 15 minutes, and it still wasn't ready, which was fine. I paid and stood nearby so they would call me when it was ready. There was a takeout bag behind the register for 20 minutes. People who ordered their food after me (in person) got their food already. When I confronted them about my order, turns out it was that bag that sat behind the counter. No apologies, at all. My fries were lukewarm and soggy by the time I got back to my hotel that was 5 minutes away. I was very disappointed. Overall, this is the type of food you would eat after going drinking. The quality is what you pay for. You get a lot of food for your buck. I recommend calling in your order, but make sure they dont forget about you.

The Best Poutine I have ever had. I love Quebec and Poutine, and this spot (pre-covid-19) was open late and popping!It's the best place in town for some amazing poutine you will ever have. If you are from LA and have had Fat Sal's, this is the Montreal version of it.

A friend recommended this restaurant to us when she found out we were going to Montreal.  She used to live there.  La Banquise was a very happening place. I had poutine the first time we went to Canada and a few times since but was never a fan.  This place had the best poutine I've ever tasted. They start off with freshly made fries as the base and then they do NOT cover it with thick gravy.  The flavors represented were fabulous. Also ordered a pogo which is just a corndog to you and I because my friend liked them, too. Lots of colorfully painted walls and tables.  Loved the feel there.  They even had branches sprawling on the ceiling itself!  Friendly wait staff. We left stuffed. Be sure to bring cash as they do not accept credit cards.  We didn't even have to wait long to get a table.  Very hard to find a parking spot though.  We ended up paying to park at a park nearby.  Would definitely return.

This is a staple stop for me whenever I visit Montreal. Quebec, in general does poutine well and here at La Banquise is no exception. I don't know how they cook their fries, but good poutine starts with a solidly good fries, cheese curds (that squeaks!!) and correct thickness of gravy.On this visit, my friends and I ordered:1. The Taquise (guacamole, sour cream and tomatoes) - light and fresh taste2. The Elvis (ground beef, peppers and mushrooms) - it didn't look good, but more than made up for it in taste3. The Panoramix (smoked meat, mushrooms and sour cream) - highlight of this visit. Anytime smoked meat is added in anything while in Montreal, I usually try. This did not disappoint!!! I was a bit iffy about the addition of sour cream, but it cut through the heaviness of smoked meat and gravy.There's always a line up here, so be prepared to wait. The staff are amazingly efficient and friendly.TIP: come between meal times, the line is manageable. We came around 3pm on a Saturday and only waited 20 mins.

Came here at around 11am on a Sunday and there was no wait. Service was fast and courteous. Ordered the regular size La Paul-Pogo (pogos, onion, bacon) poutine and it was so delicious. Note: The portion is huge and is definitely tough for one person to finish. Overall an excellent experience and would return.

*Honestly this would have been 5 stars based on the food alone however when I got my to go order I pulled out a long dark black hair out of the corner of my poutine.* After that I just was alittle grossed out to eat it.The portion that I did eat (around the area that touched the hair) was absolutely delicious! My friend got our poutines to go when we saw the long wait for a table. I got the Le Mart which had hotdog, bacon and mushrooms. You get a fairly large portion even for the "regular portion". The poutine came piled high with all the ingredients. I had to eat down till I got to the fries and cheese curds. It was delicious! The gravy is thick and the cheese curds were plenty. My friend got the trio meat poutine which she also enjoyed her poutine too. We sat at the park nearby while we ate which made it a perfect atmosphere for our little lunch. Overall much better poutine then the first place we tried when we arrived.

First time ever eating poutine. It was a delicious experience. I wish we had this in our neighborhood. The place had a "fun" vibe. Relax and casual. The staff were all very friendly. I'm amazed at the number of foodies reviews on yelp given it's a pretty long walk from the old port and located in a mixed residential area. The poutine I had was french fries topped with cut up hot dog, sausage, and bacon with the conventional cheese curds and poutine sauce. I asked for coleslaw on top. It was a mountain of yumminess I could not finish since it slayed my hunger and my belly surrendered. My ginger beer was good too. Definitely lived up to the hype. Anyone visiting Montreal must come here. Very trendy and a hopping place even on a weekday visit.

A bit rude to Anglophones. Out of courtesy, my partner greeted them in French, but after she let them know that her French was rusty their demeanor chilled considerably. It was about a 10 minute wait to order on a Saturday night. They had us pay after we ordered, which I thought was OKThe poutine was good, albeit unexceptional for the price. Given the hustle to get in, I would rather try other restaurants in the area next time I want poutine---I would guess that better poutine could be found at any local pub, rather than at a "destination" like this.

It's been years since my last visit to La Banquise but one of my cousins was obsessed with checking them out. It's close to Ma Poule Mouillée.We dropped in on a Sunday afternoon (around 2:00pm). Still blows my mind that this place is open 24/7 and has a bouncer at night. There's more than 30 types of poutines available but they also have burgers, hot dogs, salads, breakfast, desserts and drinks. They even have their own beer. - La trois viande ($16.00 large) - ground beef, pepperoni and bacon. This was really salty. - La Rachel ($14.40 large) - green peppers, mushroom and onions. The cheese curds are nice and squeaky. I liked this one better than the three meats.Obviously, this place is beloved for its poutine but I've never been a big fan of La Banquise.

February 19, 2019 - Resto La Banquise is open 24hrs and it's pretty busy for a Monday around 11:30pm.  The staff was friendly and helpful when we asked for the poutines that were mostly ordered. We ordered the La Reggae, La Savoyarde and La Sud-Ouest. We weren't sure which size to choose from regular or large. The server advised us large is double the toppings but the same amount of fries. That sounded amazing, but we got regular instead..... and we were all glad got regular. It's a lot of food!!! One regular can be shared between two ppl. So go on an empty stomach. Everything tasted very good! I would definitely recommend and hopefully if I come back to visit MTL I would go back again.

First place I actually ate at in Montreal. Came here around 2am on a Saturday and it actually wasn't a wait at all (drove past here a couple other times while in Montreal and the line was way way out the door). They actually have a big size menu, but of course we are here for the poutine. I had tried some of at least 3 different types of poutine: le duleton (ground beef and onions, pretty good), le bacon (not bad, could of used more gravy), le scooby (most-interesting, also pretty good, and unique with the fried pickles and garlic sauce). Overall the place was good, I had better poutine while in Montreal, but I would come to this landmark again, especially at 3-4am, and that's what I can say about this place, probably the best late night place to go to in Montreal. More of a 3.5 star review if anything.

We ordered to go because the wait for eating in was long. Heard from many touristy blogs that La Banquise is good... and it really is. This was my first time eating poutine and it did not disappoint. There is so much room for seating. At 1 am, the place was packed. La Banquise has so many different kinds of poutine including vegan options!! They make their own vegan gravy :') We ordered the Rachel, which was like a normal poutine but with onions, peppers and mushrooms. Fantastic. An amazing drunk food. I woke up the next morning wanting more. There was a perfect amount of gravy and cheese. The balance was great and they give you a lot of food for the large. (The photo may not be too pretty, but it was so so good)For a large, it was around 16$, which isn't too bad. Personally, I think the large is worth the money considering the small is pretty small. They take US currency, but only Canadian credit cards.

We picked up La Banquise to-go and sat down to enjoy our lunch at La Fontaine Park just across the street. We ordered the La Fred Caillou option to try a little bit of everything, this is definitely a meatlovers option. The poutine is topped with ground beef, smoked meat, spicy sausage & merguez sausage. Overall, it was great! Large portion was more than enough to share between two people, would try something different next time.
A dish of POUTINE (fries, cheese curd, gravy, apples, bacon & pulled pork).  Amazing.

For our trip to Montreal, everyone said we need to try poutine here, so we did and we didn't regret it :-)I've had poutine at various places in the US but this would be th first time in Canada and I was looking forward to it.This place is a decent size but I heard the lines can be pretty long if you go at peak times. We went around 11am and it started to fill up shortly after that.Aside from poutine they do have other items on the menu but I didn't even bother looking over there :-)I ordered the Classique and my husband got La Panoramix (included smoked meat, mushrooms, and sour cream). The Classique (with just fries, cheese curds, and gravy) was very good. The cheese curds were nice and squeaky as you chewed (which they're supposed to be) with a the gravy being well seasoned. Overall, no complaints. La Panoramix was equally good with the extra toppings adding extra flavor that all worked well together.They serve beer here (and cider) so, we both ordered a bottle. It was a baking hot day and the fact that the beer and the glasses were ice cold made the beer taste that much better.Overall a great experience and we'll be back!

I ate an entire original poutine here by myself on Instagram live once. I had 45 people watch me and it was worth it. I rolled out of there and kept on rolling home. 4 stars because I've had better poutine in Quebec City but that's just me.

Got poutine with smoked meat, which they were kind enough to put on the side since our friend couldn't have beef. The regular size of poutine was more than enough to share as an afternoon snack among three people.Food was good, not mind-blowing, but you can't come to Montreal and not have poutine and smoked meat!

This was my first visit to Montreal. It was February, so you can just imagine how cold it was. The good news, my friend and I arrived arrived around 1am and the line outside had only two people ahead of us. The bad news, once we stepped inside, there was a line of about 12 people ahead of us. All in all, I think our wait was less than 30 minutes. This was great compared to some of the reviews we had read. We were seated on the outside table. There were three people already seated on the inside. We ordered our drinks and poutine. I ordered La Sud-Ouest (Southwest) and my friend ordered La Classique (the classic), but then changed from cheese curds to mozzarella. La Sud-Ouest has bacon, red onions,  guacamole,  onion rings and a chipotle sauce. The onion rings were surprisingly crispy on top of the guacamole and with the chipotle sauce drizzled on. That means that they were cooked to order. The guacamole was very creamy. I usually like chunkier guac, but it actually worked best as creamy for the poutine because of the other ingredients. This will not be my last visit to Montreal or to La Banquise.

Last year we went to Montreal for the first time. I did some research about where to get the best poutine. La Banquise came up as the best one. So we decided to try this 24 hrs hipster joint located off a busy bike path. After a long tiring day roaming in old Montreal, we reached here around 4 PM. I was surprised to see a big line up outside a poutine restaurant. We got inside in 15 minutes. You have option to either sit inside or backyard patio. We decided the patio, as weather was amazing. They don't serve beer in patio, only inside. They serve over 30 varieties of Quebec's classic dish. My wife is vegetarian, so we decided to share a large vegetarian poutine. I must say it was finger licking good. Who doesn't love soggy fries with chewy cheese curds? It was a perfect combination of perfectly done fries, fresh cheese curds, gravy and sautéed veggies. We both loved it, it was very yummy and satisfying. I also tried ginger beer( non alcoholic), that was the best ginger beer I have ever tried, it was so refreshing. I will definitely go back and will recommend it to everyone. Because you have to try poutine at least once when you go to Montreal, so you might as well try the BEST !

This was my third visit to Canada but my first foray into the world of crispy, salted fries tossed with pillowy, tender cheese curds, then smothered in rich brown gravy.Where better to begin this journey into a plate of grease for dinner than at La Banquise, also known as poutine mecca. Open 24/7 I could see this place was popular with both daytime and nighttime crowds, a beacon of hope and refuge for the drunk, stoned, or all of the above.More than 30 poutines are available for feasting. As a first-timer I was restrained in my order, opting for the classic poutine, known as La Classique. No poutine here is for the faint of heart (or stomach) but this was a way to get my fix without tempting cardiac arrest on my first night in the city. I had a week of Montreal binge-eating to tackle, after all.As one would expect, the mix of hot, crispy, and salty fries topped with cheese and thick gravy was delicious. The cheese squeaked and the sauce was plentiful and not overly salty. There was a smoky aftertaste from the gravy that La Banquise is lauded for. The fries were piping hot, as expected from a place that has a bustling crowd and has to keep the food and drinks flowing at all hours of the day and night. The regular portion was formidable and was in fact large enough for sharing. "Let's get a burger as a side dish" is something that came out of my mouth when ordering, so we did. The standard Cheese Burger was small and simple and having a taste vaguely reminiscent of the McDonald's burger lineup. Based on other Yelp reviewer photos perhaps one of their specialty burgers with additional toppings and different meats would have been better, but the volume of food would have been overwhelming.To wash all of this goodness down I ordered a Lemoncocco, a non-carbonated drink with lemon and coconut flavors. For those going the alcoholic route there is a large menu of local microbrews, including La Banquise golden pilsner ale.I wondered about the name, as 'La Banquise' has to do with ice and they're not serving ice cream here. Apparently they did in the beginning, however, back when they opened in the 1960's. The poutine element came in the 1980's and was a hit ever since, prompting them to expand their menu significantly in the years that followed.As someone not used to eating poutine, it was a little surreal to look around and see everyone face-deep in a plate of fries for dinner, especially when they were smothered in even more stuff like guacamole, hot peppers, and multiple varieties of sausages. The dining room itself sports vividly colored walls and cactus and flower-themed table art which adds another creative and endearing layer and may help explain how La Banquise manages to stand out and attract lineups year in and year out in the heart of what's probably the world's most competitive poutine scene. La Banquise's reputation makes it a must-visit on any trip to Montreal, and if there's any place to enjoy poutine whether a first timer or an enthusiastic fan of the dish, it's here.

Do yourself a favor and get anything with the smoked meat on it. It was hands down way better than the bacon one I ordered. The poutine was good but not the best I've ever had. They were incredibly efficient. Though the restaurant was packed full we got seated quickly and our food was out in no time. The only problem we had was that they ONLY took a debit card or cash. We didn't know which was technically our fault for not doing the research but the atm fee hurt. So have cash or a debit card if you go.

Although this is the "in" place to order Poutine, I actually think their cheesburgers are way better.I tried the Poutine with hotdogs and bacon and it was just average, but the funny thing is their cheeseburgers was really good.I even tried the maple syrup soda and really did not like that at all.There are many other places in Canada that make outstanding Poutine and I guess this place is one of the originals, but I was not too impressed.

La Banquise is supposed to have the best poutine in town, and it's crazy busy. Supposedly they are busy at all hours - from noon all the way up until 6am. They have two lines, one for dine in and one for take out, and both equally long. We waited about 30-40 minutes to get takeout. We got a regular sized classic ($9), and it was nothing special. The cheese curds were chewy, but the fries were not crispy enough to hold their own against the gravy. I'd say skip this place. The wait and chaos are not worth it.

I'm not a huge fan of poutine in general, as I prefer crispy fries to soggy ones! We heard this place is a must for poutines in Montreal, so we decided to give it a try. I had the Fred which had sausages and smoked meat on top. I added some mushrooms for extra. It was good overall, but quite salty. Actually everyone at our table said their food was salty. It's not a light food so go there hungry and get an average sized poutine and you'll be set for a few hours. I won't go there again but if I did, I would get something lighter, i.e. with less toppings.

This is my first time having real Canadian poutine so I don't have much to compare it to, but it was delicious! I like all the options they have on the menu to give you a heart attack. Haha but Forreal, they have some seriously delicious options.We got the Rachel, which comes with green peppers, mushrooms, and onions. With all the flavor the gravy and cheese curds have, the veggies were a good option. It was really good! How could you go wrong with a combination of all those ingredients?

Our understanding of La Banquise is that it's especially a favorite drunk food spot for local university students. We stopped by La Banquise at almost 10 PM for a very memorable order of classic poutine. Preceding our visit to La Banquise, our car was unfortunately broken into. We weren't sure if we were going to be able to continue our Canada trip, so we needed to make sure we hit up our "must try" spots before going. My now-husband waited in the car with the busted window while I went inside to order. There are two different lines: to go and dine in. I ordered at the counter after waiting in a short line, then we received a HUGE to-go container of poutine. It was so heavy in my hand! By the time we checked into our hotel and got to eat the poutine, it was unfortunately only lukewarm (totally our fault). I so wish we could have had the experience of fresh and hot La Banquise poutine. That being said, it was still delicious and EXACTLY what we needed after the stressful break-in we experienced. There were a TON of cheese curds on top and they were squeaky perfection. We will 100% be coming back here to try more poutine the next time we come to Montreal!

La Banquise is great for a midnight snack or if you need something to soak up the alcohol. However the Poutine is pretty average here, I think people love it because there's so many different poutines you can order and it's 24 hours. We waited over an hour for 2 original poutines... that's kinda ridiculous if you ask me. Fries, Cheese & Gravy... pretty simple. Anyways I wouldn't go back for Poutine but probably for convenience.

Really packed on a Saturday night, not surprised!Heard this is the place to go for poutine and we came with a bunch of friends. Waited not too long and the staff are very courteous and polite. Amongst the loud crowds, they would notice you speaking English to your friends, and kindly offer you English menus instead of the French ones.The food however was a little underwhelming? My vision of poutine is crunchy fries soaked in gravy and melting curds. But the curds were hard, solid and stuck together, not even melted. The fries weren't even good... neither crunchy and crispy (for the parts that weren't soaked, nor thick and chewy). Disappointed for a place that specializes in fries.Note that your clothes will smell like grease after so wear something that's easily washable.

There's A LOT of places that have better poutine.And their service was the WORST.We were also treated differently than the local French speakers.From being seated to taking our order, the staff were rude and unpersonable.On top of that, we were seated for 20 minutes before they finally took our order (we flagged them, but they didn't come back for a while).But since we were pressed for time, we decided to get it to go instead. That's when they told us that they cannot accommodate us and the only way they would serve us was if we went back to the takeout line which went all the way past the storefront.And the best part was that the classic poutine came with very flimsy fries and mediocre gravy (or sub-par, but that might just be because I was bitter about it).PS This was my second visit. I really didn't enjoy the poutine on my first visit.

I remember going here with my partner almost over a year ago and remember how great the poutine was as well as not being able to finish it -- both of us!I suggest potentially sharing one if you get full easily because it's packed with food that fills you up.I'd definitely come back here again!

I believe this place is considered a tourist trap but we didn't care- we wanted to try their crazy poutine concoctions! We got the reggae to go and headed to the nearby park to eat it and enjoy being outside. I liked that it was different from regular poutine but it also made me crave the classic. Overall it was a good size but I wish there were more toppings for a more balanced fry ratio. It was a nice place to try but not the best poutine. If you want the best poutine ever then you have to go to ***Paradis BBQ*** I know it might seem strange to go to a chicken spot for poutine but seriously...if our Airbnb host did not tell us about it we would have never known. Their chicken and mashed potatoes are amazing too but their POUTINE omg.
The best Poutine restaurant around.  The service is kind of slow and at times rude.  But you can't beat the Poutine and the price.  Must try when visiting Montreal, will not be disappointed.

Delicious! Tons of options which was amazing, I got a vegan poutine and my friend got Fred.... with onion rings. Both were delicious! Service was nice even though it was take out only (b/c coronavirus).

We decided to try this place after reading all the reviews. There was a line, but it did not take long to be seated. They have a wide variety of poutine and the service was quick. We tried a variation from the meat to the vegan poutine. It was good but average poutine, but the cheese curds were really good.

On vacation we came here because it's so highly rated so we figured why not the line was out the door but they move very quickly and we got sat in less than 15 minutes if you are looking for a restaurant that will actually provide you with full service from a waiter then this is not the place for youour server took our order and we never saw her again, for us we didn't mind because we like a fast service and other workers are constantly walking around so you can ask them if you need any other help POUTINE ok for me, the actually fry itself, i was not a fan of, it was sweet and i didn't appreciate that subtle sweetness in the fryhowever the gravy was AMAZING!! overall i was VERY happy with my food and i can see why the line is always out the door

The BEST poutine!!! I came around lunchtime, there was already a line out the door but it moves quickly. I ended up ordering to go, and I got a large classic poutine. It took a while to come out, but was def worth the wait. The gravy was so delicious. The fries themselves were also very good. It was the perfect mix. Portions are pretty big . I felt so satisfied and fat after, I would definelty come back to eat this again.

Yes, come here. I love fries but never enjoyed poutine much, as it always seemed unnecessarily over the top (I have the same sentiment with nachos). Well, La Banquise does poutine well. Lines were long Saturday night, but it moved along and you are given a buzzer for when your order is ready, which I always appreciate. I went with the Rachel, and it was delishhh. The onions, mushrooms, peppers, curds, gravy all went so well together with the perfectly textured fries.

Wow.  Way to make tourists feel unwelcome.  Well done, Montreal.We came in at noon on a Sunday and the place was dead.  We were a party of 6 and asked to be seated outside.  We were seated and given menus and then ignored purposefully for 15 minutes.  We attempted to flag down 2 servers who were serving the tables around us and they walked passed us and wouldn't acknowledge us.Finally the hostess came by and we asked to be served and she went to find our server, returned minutes later and said, "Guess I'm taking your order."  She took it, left, returned another 5 minutes later and said, "Cook says it'll be over 40 minutes for your food.  Do you just want to leave?"  We we're shocked and said no since we'd driven here specifically to try the poutine since we'd been recommended here by a local.  So we cancelled our burgers and sandwiches and asked just to get our soda and poutine.  That came out within 5 minutes... then they told us they only will accept Canadian money.  Cash only.  AFTER we ordered food.  Luckily we scrambled enough together with tip despite it being our last day and ready to leave the country.It was a little warm outside so we asked the first server we saw if we could have the fan on that was over our table.  The server simply said "yeah" in an annoyed tone without making eye contact and walked away.  So we tried to figure it out for ourselves.  A minute later, he came out and turned on another fan for the other tables without them even asking.And now for the poutine.  Eh.  Not that great.FURTHERMORE a table who came after us received their burgers minutes after we received our poutine.  Which means they purposefully lied to make us leave.  Wow.  WOW.Oh and their bathroom air dryers didn't work and had no soap. Nasty.If you're not from Montreal, DO NOT EAT HERE.

Hooray, finally taking La Banquise off my bookmarks!  According to most Montreal 'must do' lists, this is one of THE places to go for poutine.  Overall I would agree...we came in mid-afternoon on a Monday, and were fortunate to get a seat right away on the terrasse. They have a variety of poutines to try out and they all looked amazing! But I am a poutine purist....give me my fries, curds, and gravy and I am good.  Signs of a good poutine:1. Squeaky cheese curds.  Check.2. Crispy perfect fries.  Check (for the most part)3. Flavorful gravy that is not too salty. Check.What would have made this a full-on 5 star review would have been double frying the fries...but that is just a matter of preference.  That said, it was a pretty darn good poutine!Service was also quite attentive and friendly.  I will definitely make my way back here again on a next visit.

When in Montreal,Never miss..never come back without having a poutine. Specially hereLoved the food very much.Location  - 6/10 (Street Side place, Park view, Uptown)Parking - 5/10 ( Limited Street parking, public parking at a distance )Menu Options - 9/10 ( Made live, Tasty, The famous poutine)Service Quality - 9/10 ( Fast, Prompt & Courteous) Value for money - 8/10 (Tasty, simple and small menu )Seating Comfort -  7/10 (non cushioned, Indoor, Outdoor )Noise Level - 8/10 ( 10 Being High )Cleanliness - 9/10 ( Overall Tidy, neat Restrooms)

Knocking a star because they kept seating us, and other people, under a drippy ceiling. Otherwise, wow! The poutine options here and unending. Vegetarian, vegan, meat-filled, whatever you need! I got the goat cheese, which was an up charge, but they gave SO much cheese! Meat was flavorful and matched well with the fries. Even with the smaller size, everyone at my table had at least half of their basket left over, and I love reheated fries, so we threw them together and brought them home.Twas quite full on a Sunday late afternoon, so took a minute to order and get our food, but not long enough to complain. They have beer as well, and an outdoor seating area in the back, so drop by, have a Cheval Blanc, and sit in the autumn weather on a boozy evening or a lazy afternoon!
Good, but not the best.A landmark, good vibe, but definitely a tourist destination.24h service appreciated.

Maybe it's psychological. The anticipation of standing in line for 40 minutes increases both the appetite and heightens expectations, leaving the customer in a state of euphoria or setting her/him up for utter disappointment. I definitely fell into the former category. First let me say that, although it was rainy and cold as nipples, I adored Montreal. It reminded me a lot of Chicago, which is my favorite city in the universe. And every great city has to have a hook. For Chi, it's deep dish pizza. For Montreal, it seems to be poutine. And La Banquise reminds me a lot of Giordano's, the popular deep dish pizzeria. They didn't invent it, but they sure did popularize it. La Banquise is fun. Graffiti decorates the walls, while pop culture decorates the tables, and epic pop music (so bad, it's good) decorates the airwaves. Our experience was part art diner, part sing-along, and part heart attack on a plate. The tricky part is that we don't eat meat, yet they are clear on what's vegan, what's veggie-friendly, and what has meat parts. So, that was our main motivation in going here. I got the veggie burger, which was satisfying enough, but clearly no one goes to La Banquise for a burger. The poutine is the focal point. We got one that wasn't listed on the website, but dons the wall. And it was soooooo good. Maybe it's just because cheese and gravy makes everything taste better. If they opened up one of these in the states, I'd be there in a heart...beat.

Literally Poutine Heaven!!!! La Banquise is the most popular Poutine in Montreal, offering a variety of different toppings to add on to a traditional one. I enjoyed heavily mine and would return for more. The only issue is that the lines can get long. It was freezing outside so if you go during the late fall into winter, you better be bundled up. The staff was attentive and kind so I rate them 5/5. If the wait wasn't too long then they would be a 5/5. As a tip, split one with a friend or a significant other. The portions are large.

WOW the line for this place was RIDICULOUS. it was 830 pm and it was super long! not one line but two lines put the door! we got close to the front of the shop and the host came out looking for a party of two so lucky us! we got seated and were given menus. it was very crowded inside as well as hot! we ordered the classic poutine and the 3 amigos poutine. they both came out fairly quick. unfortunately every fry was soft/soggy. even the ones that weren't covered in any sauce.  i usually like crispy fries so i was let down by that. maybe we had a bad batch? regardless, the flavor of the sauce was on point. the sausages in the 3 amigos were really good as well.unfortunately they also don't accept credit cards unless it's canadian debit or canadian/usd cash. being from the states that was inconveniencing to us. thankfully my boyfriend carried usd cash on him but we were definitely short changed by about 7$. very aggravating and annoying. so wasn't a fan of that.when we left, the lines looked like they hadn't moved at all and it was just as busy! unfortunately i don't think i would come visit again. i'll try the poutine place across the street next time.

4.5 Did you even visit Montreal if you didn't go to La Banquise? It was a hot summer day, the hottest of the year so far in fact, and I ventured all the way to this plateau landmark for some delicious poutine. The storefront is old, but it's seems well maintained. The place was packed despite it being 10 PM - apparently this place is always busy. I placed my order for takeout because the restaurant was full and also there was no AC inside... On the day I went their fridge had broken down so they didn't have all the ingredients to make every type of poutine, but they had their basics and I just wanted the classic...they have vegan and vegetarian options which are made with mushroom gravy - and if you want vegan cheese curds they have that for an added price. There is quite a bit of a wait to get the food - I would say at least 10-15 minutes, but it's well worth the wait. The poutine is prepared fresh and tastes amazing. The fries were crispy, the gravy was hefty and satisfying, and the cheese curds were salty and perfectly mixed together. Definitely check out this place if you have time!

I'm 'sorry' to have to do this but, I've thought about it and for the actual Traditional Poutine, I've got to give it the 'ol two star rating. The service, décor and even the nice stone tiled bathrooms get a three, but per their 'famous' dish that people stand in line for (almost all the time) - pretty disappointing. In summary, the fries were fine and even above average, but then it just goes sideways. The gravy was blah, and was hard to find as maybe it contained a half or small ladle's worth. The cheese curd was the most disappointing part of it; a minimal portion, too dense and no 'squeak' factor. I don't think I have to go on much further to justify my rating, and yes I'm aware it's on most tourism lists, and surely fits the bill as a late night junk food place - being open 24 hours and all. Again, the overall is more than a two star experience, but I think that it needs to be pointed out that there are many many better Tradition Poutines around town, and dare I say across the country. 'Sorry' again.Note: The topped versions, and other items looked decent - visually.

First off, poutine is one of the top foods to eat in the province of Quebec....read this National Geographic article from September 14, 2010:nationalgeographic.com/t…Never having poutine before, I asked some locals where their favorite spot is in Montréal. Most recommended La Banquise. I found out why. Craving some smoked meat, the logical choice of poutine was L'Obelix. The cheese curds are the star as they start to melt from the heat of the fries and gravy. Paired with a local provincial beer, it was the perfect meal before catching a hockey game at the Bell Center. I enjoyed it so much, I went back again later in the week to try another poutine (La Rachel-green pepper, mushroom, onion). I think I was deprived a guiltless pleasure in my youth.

We enjoyed our poutine at La Banquise. La Banquise has a lot of variety on what is served on their poutine and you can see that the employees enjoy working here. I appreciated the energy the workers bring to the restaurant. However, I preferred Ma Poule Mouillée across the street. La Banquise lacked the spice and flavor that Ma Poule does so well.

Phenomenal all around! We got the popo (corn dog) and smoked meats poutines - both "regular" size. In addition to being delicious, they are a solid amount of food. Between the two of us we housed the 2 poutines for lunch, and didn't need any more food. Was fun to try the bec (maple-syrup flavored, caffeine free) cola too.Really glad a coworker recommended we check out La Banquise while we were visiting Montreal. Would highly recommend and will definitely be back next time we're in Montreal!! Heads up - They're cash only. They will take USD at 1.15 (at least that was the rate they gave us when we were there).

First and foremost, this was a great atmosphere. I heard there is usually a long wait to get in, but I didn't experience that as I was able to basically walk in and get a table late Thursday night. There were good options for vegetarian/vegan, both poutine and otherwise. I ended up opting for a non-vegan poutine because I wanted those cheese curds. It was pretty good, but I would have liked the fries to be crispier. The veggie burger was satisfactory. I went with the classic poutine this time, but would probably experiment with some of the different options, though most of them are meat-centric. The staff spoke pretty decent English, so the whole experience was smooth for sure.
I was seated quickly but I sat there for 10 minutes and not one person came over to take my order or to greet me so I got up and left
First time trying poutine, delicious but very heavy which I was prepared for. Must try once if your digestive system is fine with that. The place was very busy, there was a line but went fast.

Are you ready to line up, rain or shine?I promise you, it's worth it!We visited La Banquise last night after just arriving in Montreal for technically the first time (for me, anyways). From afar, we could already see the long lineup before parking the car...It was about a half an hour wait, but we were told sometimes it could be a couple hour wait. So test your luck! They've got a huge selection of fresh poutines, and additional toppings that you can add onto it as well. Meanwhile, I was craving spaghetti, so we got that on the side as well. It's a casual ambience here with quick service. A little tip? They only accept cash or debit at this location, so come prepared!If you're looking for a must-visit place in Montreal for their well-known Poutine? Trust me, this is the spot :)
Their poutine was absolutely delicious!!! I ordered the poutine with smoked meat and it was amazing! The smoked meat had a smokey flavor and was tender.

After many online recommendations and friends who loved this place, we came here for dinner. How could we visit Montreal without having their poutine? The lineup was very long, which is a good sign. We chose to get takeout quicker and eat in a local park. Really nothing bad I can say about this place. It is pricy for the regular sized poutine, but very much worth the experience. I ordered "La Sud-Ouest" which consisted of fries, gravy, onion rings, red onions, bacon, guacamole, and chipotle sauce. I recommend the regular size per individual, or even splitting a large.

It goes without saying that eating poutine is a must in Montreal. With poutineries all over the city it can make it challenging for a visitor to find the best spot. After reading a few reviews la banquise was the winner for me and my friends. We arrived around 11:30 with no line at all which was great. We sat got sat immediately to what seemed like the last open table in this super busy spot. It has the vibe of a diner being open 24Hr and  a menu of basic crowd pleasing food. What is not basic is the long list of the many poutines they offer. The portions are really big and with me not being a huge gravy fan I decided just to steal a couple bites off my friends poutine. She ordered the classic poutine and I ordered a hot dog with cheese. The food came out very quickly and it was good. Like I previously mentioned I am not a huge fan of gravy so the amazingness of poutine is a bit lost on me. But for what is it it hit the spot. I asked for my hot dog well done and it wasn't crispy at all but it was still tasty. When we left the line was very long to get in so if you are planning to check this spot out come a little before the lunch rush begins or prepare to wait.

Poutine, Poutine, Poutine--- where to find the poutine!Despite having this place bookmarked-- It didn't cross my mind until our Uber driver recommended it to us. I hadn't planned on going up towards Plateau area, but La Banquise brought me there in search of Quebecois take on Poutine. This place was definitely a fed the masses kinda place, and quite honestly, I don't know if I enjoy this place sober, or if I would have enjoyed it a bit more after a long drunken night of shenanigans. I tried the Panoramix. It was a toss up between that, or the Scooby, which the person next to me ended up ordering, and I was a little jealous. I ordered the Panoramix as I didn't get a chance to add a smoked meat place into my trip, so in killing two birds with one stone-- It sufficed. It's a gargantuan amount of food, even for the smaller portion. It really indulges the US quantity in portion sizing. It was a beautiful day, so we fully took advantage of the back patio along with a lot of others. It did not disappoint! The servers were also very courteous and kind, despite me trying my hardest, but ma francais est terrible!La Banquise hit the spot, and the best part is that Parc la Fontaine is less than a skip away, so go work off some of that gluttony with a walk around the ponds!Overall it was a good experience-- I don't know if I would have condoned waiting for a long time to eat here, and it certainly isn't busy during the week days.

La Banquise will always be a recommendation I give to first-timers in Montreal - delicious poutine and open 24/7!I ordered La Matty and my boyfriend ordered La Reggae, both of which were delicious. It is definitely more expensive poutine, but well worth it for the amount of food you get and the ingredients they add. I actually preferred La Reggae because of the guac and it was somewhat lighter than La Matty. I would definitely recommend something with a guacamole or sour cream topping. The only reason La Banquise loses a star is because it is ALWAYS busy. Expect to wait at least 30 minutes for a seat inside. The place is very casual and has a very generic interior, but great for groups. However, I ONLY recommend being seated at the restaurant for the patio during the summer. Tip: To avoid the line, order it to go and head over to a nearby park or back to your place (it's really not that nice inside, so you're not missing out on much!).
Here we have an old Quebec lady making poutine that would literally melt your heart. Cheese curds were perfect, gravy was piping and oozing, and the fries were unlike any poutine I've ever had.

Definitely a place for the bucket list if you're in Montreal. There's usually a line out front, but it's worth the wait for sure. The tables are a little cramped and the restaurant itself can get a little extra toasty from the congestion, but the poutine is on point! The fries had just enough sauce to cover them without being drowned and the cheese on top had great flavor (although in the future I'll ask for extra cheese but that's just personal preference). They have so many varieties so you can get creative or just stick to the classics - whatever you're in the mood for.Then only drawbacks: the patio outside isn't allowed to serve alcohol and they only accept cash. Overall I really liked my experience here and would come back again!

Overall - wide variety of poutine to choose from. Great outdoor seating and it's right next to a beautiful park. Everything tasted great and I would recommend it to inexperienced poutine eaters like me who want to try the classic as well as other varieties of it.Pros - variety of the poutines as well as the well balanced flavors. Some bad poutines that I've had were very salty (I assume the gravy just kept on reducing )but this was well-balanced and delicious.Cons - no cons but not a place that makes you jump out of your seat either.

This was the last place we went to before leaving montreal. I have never tasted Poutine this good!!! I got the La Reggea Poutine and my husband got the pork poutine and both were equally as good. I have an allergy and when I told them about it they too it very seriously. The food was fresh. the ambience is so cheerful I was just excited to be there too!! Best poutine and so many options. They really make you feel welcome.

When in Montreal, one must indulge in poutine. And on that note,  I came to La Banquise. (why settle for anything but the best,  amirite?!) Unfortunately,  I assumed people would be done eating by 730pm, and when I arrived,  there was a line up out the door.  Luckily, there are 2 separate lines; one for dine in and one for take out (there is clear signage indicating this on the door and on the window. As you're facing the door,  right hand side is the dine in line, your left is the take out line). The take out line was much shorter and it meant I didn't have to stand out in the freezing cold, so I chose to take out instead.  They have a pretty extensive menu, but I opted for the classic poutine. You have your choice between regular and large sizes (take out containers are made of cardboard btw, for all you environmental minded folks).  I ordered the regular size,  and they fill the containers pretty generously,  so I was quite satisfied afterwards.
